docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your article on the Park Slope Food Cooperative (''Food Co-op Bitter to the Core,'' Jan. 26) inaccurately quoted me as voicing fear that someone might bring a gun to a meeting. My intent was to convey the depth of feeling this is...
docs.abstract: Letter by Stewart Martin, board member of Park Slope Food Co-op, disputes Jan 26 article on the co-op (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your article on the Park Slope Food Cooperative (''Food Co-op Bitter to the Core,'' Jan. 26) inaccurately quoted me as voicing fear that someone might bring a gun to a meeting. My intent was to convey the depth of feeling this issue has conjured up. The article also portrayed the situation as a power struggle between three board members and the co-op managers, which it never was. The three dissenting board members have always sought to increase representative democracy.

headline.main: Quotation on Food Co-op Unduly Inflamed Passions

docs.snippet: NEW YORKERS who have been craving lobster at midnight or steak at 6 A.M. will soon have a huge warehouse market to satisfy their desires.         Chelsea Market, a complex of wholesale markets that will also sell to retail  customers, is beginning...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORKERS who have been craving lobster at midnight or steak at 6 A.M. will soon have a huge warehouse market to satisfy their desires. Chelsea Market, a complex of wholesale markets that will also sell to retail customers, is beginning to take shape in a building that runs from Ninth Avenue to 10th, between 15th and 16th Streets. It will be open to the public at the end of May, and many of the merchants are planning to stay open 24 hours a day. Which will be just fine with workers in the television, film and photography studios on the upper floors of the 10-story building at 88 10th Avenue. Chefs who need ingredients late in the evening or on weekends, when regular wholesale markets are closed, will also benefit.

headline.main: Chelsea to Add a 24-Hour Food Market

docs.snippet: Organic and Convenient    Fresh Fields, which is known for its high-quality supermarkets that stock extensive organic products, expects to open convenience stores in New York. It plans to sell produce and other perishable foods in partnership with...
docs.lead_paragraph: Organic and Convenient Fresh Fields, which is known for its high-quality supermarkets that stock extensive organic products, expects to open convenience stores in New York. It plans to sell produce and other perishable foods in partnership with Richard Melman's Lettuce Entertain You Enterprises in Chicago. "We hope to have at least one store in Manhattan before the end of the year," said Mark Ordan, the president of Fresh Fields, based in Rockville, Md. He said the partnership planned to open 8 to 10 stores a year in New York, Chicago and other cities in both urban and suburban locations. "We think there's a real demand out there that is not being filled," he said.

docs.snippet: IN the beginning was the kitchen of Nelson Yeung's restaurant in Patchogue, L.I., and it was hot.   "One hundred and ten degrees in that kitchen," Mr. Yeung recalled recently. "You don't need 110 degrees. We figured out restaurant working is too h...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the beginning was the kitchen of Nelson Yeung's restaurant in Patchogue, L.I., and it was hot. "One hundred and ten degrees in that kitchen," Mr. Yeung recalled recently. "You don't need 110 degrees. We figured out restaurant working is too hard."

headline.main: Duck Sauce: Rarely Put on Duck, and a Lot Is Made in Jersey

docs.snippet: Instant Oktoberfest    Oktoberfest, the annual German beer celebration, began in 1810 as extended festivities for the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig of Bavaria. The largest Oktoberfest is still the one in Munich, where more than a million gallons...
docs.lead_paragraph: Instant Oktoberfest Oktoberfest, the annual German beer celebration, began in 1810 as extended festivities for the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig of Bavaria. The largest Oktoberfest is still the one in Munich, where more than a million gallons of beer are consumed at the annual 16-day citywide party. Now, you can organize your own Oktoberfest, albeit on a more modest scale -- for just an afternoon, perhaps, and with a few six-packs. An "Oktoberfest Kit" by Jim Horzen comes complete with an instruction book that illustrates traditional Bavarian costumes and dances and suggests the appropriate kinds of beer and food, including recipes.

docs.snippet: At the New Barneys Store    Mad.61, the sleek and inviting food complex on the lower level of the new Barneys store at Madison Avenue and 61st Street, is a combination restaurant, cafe, espresso bar, wine bar and takeout shop with some novel aspec...
docs.lead_paragraph: At the New Barneys Store Mad.61, the sleek and inviting food complex on the lower level of the new Barneys store at Madison Avenue and 61st Street, is a combination restaurant, cafe, espresso bar, wine bar and takeout shop with some novel aspects: all the food, both packaged and prepared, is available for tasting, and all of the wines bear numerical ratings. "If anyone sees something on the shelves they want to taste, we'll crack it open and let them taste," said Steven Jenkins, a consultant who has selected the cheeses and packaged foods at Mad.61. Italian Parmigiano-Reggiano is priced at $10 a pound, reblochon is $13.50 and St.-Nectaire is $11; in fact, very few of the carefully selected cheeses on display are priced at less than $10 a pound.

docs.snippet: Eating U.S.A.     "The practice of medicine would be made much easier if I could persuade my male patients to diet more and my female patients to diet less." These words, which sound so familiar, are surprising only because they were written 60 ye...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eating U.S.A. "The practice of medicine would be made much easier if I could persuade my male patients to diet more and my female patients to diet less." These words, which sound so familiar, are surprising only because they were written 60 years ago, back in 1933, in an article called "The Rise and Fall of Food Fads" that appeared in American Mercury magazine. They are quoted in a new book, "Paradox of Plenty," by Harvey Levenstein (Oxford University Press, $27.50), a compelling history of food and eating in modern America.
